Column Comment.0: CIRCULATION ID: Unique Circulation identifier for a record of a data circulation.
Column Comment.1: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.2: AUTHORIZED BY: Name of the person who authorized the circulation.
Column Comment.3: BUSINESS ASSOCIATE: Unique identifier for a business associate, such as aperson, company, regulatory agency, government or consortium.
Column Comment.4: CIRCULATION DUE DATE: The date when the item is to be returned
Column Comment.5: CIRCULATION IN DATE: The date when the item is actually returned
Column Comment.6: CIRCULATION DATE: Date on which the item was checked out
Column Comment.7: CONDITION IN: Condition in which the item was returned. Can be used to updateData item condition attribute. Also kept here to allow historical tracking (who has areputation for damaging sections.)
Column Comment.8: CONDITION OUT: describes the condition of the data when it was checked out. Thisis used where historical information is needed (track people or companies whofrequently damage items).
Column Comment.9: STATUS: Status of the item, such as checked in or out.
Column Comment.10: DATA_CONTENT_SEQ_NO: sequence number which allows the ennumeration ofthe contents of a file folder etc (physical item is a file folder, information item is thefield notes, the ennumeration lists all the components of the field notes, if desired).
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: INFORMATION ITEM ID: Unique identifier for the information item.
Column Comment.14: INFORMATION ITEM SUBTYPE: the type of information item. May be one of Thevalid types of Information item as defined by check constraints.
Column Comment.15: PHYSICAL ITEM ID: The unique identifier for the physical item.
Column Comment.16: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.17: PROJECT IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the project.
Column Comment.18: PROJECT STEP IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the step in the project that hasresulted in this circulation record.
Column Comment.19: REFERENCE NUMBER: Reference number such as contract number, work order orpurchase order number.
Column Comment.20: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.21: RESERVED BY: unique id for the business associate who has reserved this item.
Column Comment.22: RESERVED INDICATOR: indicates whether the physical item has been reservedduring the current circulation. Binary flag; does not indicate who reserved for or whenreserved.
Column Comment.23: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.24: STATUS DATE: The date on which the current status was created.
Column Comment.25: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.26: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.27: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.28: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.29: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.30: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.31: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
